letters.reason: Letter starts with 'Toronto, den 11. Nov.' and 'Liebe Mutti!'. The content flows from political concerns about Europe, to Ursel's health, to news about Inge and Klaus returning, and finally a plan to visit New York. The closing 'Herzlichen Gruß Inge' on the last page fits, although the sender's name is Inge, while the content seems to be from the usual writer (Dolfi/Jork?). This is a slight ambiguity.

Letter starts with 'Toronto, den 16. Dez. 56' and 'Liebe Christel!'. The first page mentions a missing part of Christel's letter. The second page directly references this, asking Christel to look for the beginning of her letter. It then lists Christmas wishes and ends with a clear closing and signature 'viele Grüße an dich und die anderen drei, von Dolfi'.

Letter starts with 'Toronto, den 15 Dez. 56' and 'Liebes Mech!'. The pages discuss Christmas and New Year's plans at the cottage with the same group of friends (Inge, Klaus, Siegfried, Käthe, Gisela). The content flows from Christmas plans, to Christmas Eve at the cottage, to New Year's plans. The final page has a New Year's greeting.

Letter starts with 'Toronto, Dez. 27, 56' and 'Liebe Mutter!'. It begins by thanking for a Christmas package including records. The second page mentions receiving a record from 'Gisel' for birthday and Christmas. The third page mentions a Beethoven record and asks about 'meine Gitarre', which connects to other letters. The flow is somewhat disjointed but the topics are consistent.

Letter starts with 'Toronto, den 29.1.,57' and 'Liebe Mutter!'. The first page thanks for a Christmas package and describes the winter weather. The second page discusses films and mentions a play being performed in 'Hamilton', which is a recurring topic.

Letter starts with 'Toronto, Feb. 2, 57' and 'Liebe Mutti!'. The first page discusses Christel's glasses that make things look smaller. The second page continues this exact topic, describing the author's own new glasses which no longer have this effect, and ends with a signature.

Letter starts with 'Toronto, den 12. April, 57' and 'Liebe Mutter!'. The first page discusses Easter and mentions Gisela. The second page continues by mentioning a birthday gift from Gisela ('Der Himmel voller geigen') and the upcoming performance of 'Jolanthe' in the church, a recurring theme. It ends with a closing and signature 'herzliche grüße von Jork'.

Letter starts with 'Toronto, den 2. Mai 57' and 'Liebe Mutter!', wishing her a happy 51st birthday. The second page continues the theme of spring/Easter and asks for the guitar to be sent with Inge and Klaus. The third page discusses VW service, prices in Canada, and asks a series of family questions, fitting for a letter home. It ends with a closing from 'Karl'.

Letter starts with 'Toróls den 21. Juni' (likely Toronto) and 'Liebe Mutter!'. The first page mentions various group activities, including the 'Jolanthe' play. The second page continues seamlessly, describing a new 'Volkstanzgruppe' and an international folk festival. The third page continues describing the festival and mentions needing the guitar, linking back to other letters. The content flow is very strong.

Letter starts with 'Toronto, den 14. Aug. 57' and 'Liebe Mutti!'. The first page discusses plans to come home for Christmas and a recent trip. The second page discusses family matters (Christel's and Dagmar's exams) and the author's job at the bank. The third page continues the topic of the 'Jolanthe' play in Hamilton and a love for the American West, which connects to the travel theme from page one.

This is a single page that appears to be a complete letter. It is somewhat fragmented but contains a clear closing 'Herzliche Weihnachts- und Neujahrsgrüße von Deinem Karl'. It discusses travel plans to Alaska and financial matters.
